Using TDD (mocha, chai), write a function `addNumbersInString(string)`, that returns the sum of all the numbers contained within the string. The function should treat adjacent numbers as a single number, and, should handle numbers prefaced with a `-`, treating them as negative.

Example:


`addNumbersInString('3abcde7fg2');` // 12
`addNumbersInString('3abcde17fg2');` // 22
`addNumbersInString('3abcde-17fg2');` // -12
`addNumbersInString('3a1000bcde-17fg2');` // 988
`addNumbersInString('abcdefg');` // 0
`addNumbersInString('');` // 0

<!channel> Here's the hacky notes from the break out in 2 chunks:

```
const express = require('express');

// let's pretend we have a config object here
// with details about how to connect to an actual
// postgres server somewhere
const knex = require('knex')(config);

const app = express();
const Names = require('./Names');


app.get('/get/:id', (req, res) => {
  let names = new Names()
  let promiseFromQuery = names.getANameFromData(req.params.id);

  promiseFromQuery
    .then(names => {
      if (!names) {
        res.status(404).send('No value')
      }
      res.json(names);
    })
    .catch(err => {
      res.status(500).send(err)
    });
});

app.get('/get', (req, res) => {
  let promiseFromQuery = getNamesFromData();

  promiseFromQuery
    .then(names => {
      if (!names) {
        res.status(404).send('No value')
      }
      res.json(names);
    })
    .catch(err => {
      res.status(500).send(err)
    });
});
```

```
class Names {
  constructor() {
  }

  getNamesFromData() {
    let promiseFromQuery = knex('ourTable')
      .select('names')
      .then(names => {
        res.json(names)
      })
  }

  getANameFromData(id) {
    let promiseFromQuery = knex('ourTable')
      .where('id', id)
      .select('names')

    return promiseFromQuery;
  }
}

module.exports = Names;
```

when we `build` an app we do things like minify our files (removing whitespace) and concatinating them into one big file...not so nice for developing, but great for deploying our app so that it travels more quickly over the internet.
The fact that the application is in React is not important for this particular lesson. It could be any front end app, including those that you have build in Q1

<!channel> here are the lesson notes that were taken this morning should you wish to use them for review:

```
STEPS NEEDED TO REUSE AN APPLICATION ELSEWHERE

install express and other application dependencies
configure access to the db
install the database
seed and configure the db
be able to handle requests over some network
  (have an OS similar enough to mine)
we need provide build steps (and they need to be run)
Commit our source code to version control
Make ENVs and api keys somehow available (maybe with a script)


POTENTIAL PROBLEMS WHEN SCALING MASSIVELY
Some remaining potential problems, especially in the production environment

  If our app is big, deploying a new version can take a long time
    just redeploy one container

  Developing means developing on the whole code base, which introduces complexity and cognitive overhead
    just develop on a containerized "Service (aka microservice)"

  If part of the app crashes, the whole app crashes
    nope, just the container (ms to spin back up)

  What if we want to use two different versions of a program on our OS? (say python?)
    no problem

  If we want to scale a part of our application, we have to scale the whole thing
    scale a given service (container)

WHAT DOCKER PROVIDES USERS

The tools that Docker provides

  Run containers from already existing images
  Inspect and interact with containers
  Create new images
  Store and retrieve images from version control
  Launch applications composed of many different containers
  Handle communication between different containers
  Scale running containers
  Create new virtual machines on cloud providers to be used with Docker
  Scale containers across multiple machines

SPECIFIC DOCKER COMMANDS
The specific commands that Docker provides

`docker`
  Run containers from already existing images
  Inspect and interact with containers
  Create new images
  Store and retrieve images from version control

`docker-compose`
  Launch applications composed of many different containers
  Handle communication between different containers
  Scale running containers

`docker-machine`
  Create new virtual machines on cloud providers to be used with Docker

Swarm mode (previously `docker-swarm`)
  Scale containers across multiple machines
`docker ps` shows all running containers
`docker images` shows installed images

`docker` SUB COMMAND LIST

`docker run` run a container from a given image (with an optional command)
`docker run -it` run a container from a given image with the terminal available to us


`docker logs` allows us to see the standard output of a container

`docker images` shows all the images we have installed locally

`docker rm` to remove a container
```

I notice several of you are working on a part of the Pet Shop deliverable that requires the use of the `body-parser` library, which <@U59LA2656> will be covering in class tomorrow. Here's a little bit of a body parser crash course to help you get started.

`body-parser` can be installed with `npm install --save body-parser` and it will give you access to a special collection of _middleware_ functions.

If you use these middleware functions _prior_ to writing `POST` request handler functions, then the `req` object inside the handlers will be given an additional property `body`, which contains the body of the post _request_.

Therefore, after installing `body-parser` with `npm` you can, _before_ your route handlers, add the following code to be able to access the body of the request.

```
const bodyParser = require('body-parser');
app.use(bodyParser.json());
app.use(bodyParser.urlencoded({ extended: false }));
```

Now, inside your post handlers you can access the special `body` property on the `req` object:

```
<http://app.post|app.post>('/pets', (req, res) => {
  console.log(req.body); // will log the body of the incoming POST request
}
```

More details on how this works tomorrow with <@U59LA2656>. Best!

<!channel>. Here's a slight refactor of the problem from this morning. Feel free to play around with the constants to get meaningful information about the top HN stories, and or write your own helper functions to be able to extract other meaningful data. GREAT WORK ON PROMISES THIS WEEK! I trust y'all are gonna be SUPER comfortable with them after you've used them in your own code for a while:

```
const NUMBER_OF_STORIES_TO_FETCH = 500;
const MINIMUM_NUMBER_OF_COMMENTS = 80;

getHNStoriesDataForTop(NUMBER_OF_STORIES_TO_FETCH)
  .then(stories => getStoriesWithDescendantsMoreThan(MINIMUM_NUMBER_OF_COMMENTS, stories))
  .then(getStoryTitles)
  .then(console.log)
  .catch(handleError);

/*
 * Get data on the top HN stories
 */

function getHNStoriesDataForTop(num) {
  // API URLs
  const topStoriesURL = '<https://hacker-news.firebaseio.com/v0/topstories.json>';
  const itemURL = '<https://hacker-news.firebaseio.com/v0/item/>'; // <--- don't forget id and .json

  let storiesData = fetch(topStoriesURL)
    .then(topStoriesResponse => topStoriesResponse.json())
    .then(topStoriesIds => {
      let topStoryRequests = topStoriesIds.slice(0, num).map((id) => fetch(`${itemURL}${id}.json`));
      return Promise.all(topStoryRequests);
    })
    .then(topStoryResponses => {
      let topStoryJsonPromises = topStoryResponses.map(topStoryResponse => topStoryResponse.json());
      return Promise.all(topStoryJsonPromises);
    })
    .catch(handleError);

  return storiesData;
}


/*
 * Given storiesData, get their titles
 */

function getStoryTitles(stories) {
  let storyTitles = stories.map(story => story.title);
  return storyTitles;
}

/*
 * Given storiesData, get filter by those with more than 10 descendants
 */

function getStoriesWithDescendantsMoreThan(num, stories) {
  let storiesWithDescendantsMoreThan = stories.filter(story => story.descendants > num);
  return storiesWithDescendantsMoreThan;
}

/*
 * Utility functions
 */

function handleError(err) {
  throw new Error(`Error handling promise: ${err}`);
}
```

<!channel> a couple of you have asked about D3 and/or C3 which are both JavaScript libraries to support making visualization based on a data set. For those of you who are interested in exploring either of these libraries, I want to support you!

Here's the thing, you don't yet have a lot of experience using third party libraries with very little support. This is a skill that all of you will learn as we work through the course, but at this time, some of you will be better at it than others. With that in mind, if you are interested in exploring C3 or D3 (or any other library that is novel that will support your work, *timebox between 1 and 2 hours strictly to learn and BUILD something simple with the library**. After that period of time, decide once and for all if you are willing to take on the extra load of working with the 3rd party library, which of course might reap great rewards.

Regarding C3 and D3 specifically. C3 is much easier to use, and provides a much more limited feature set. D3, while more challenging allows you to do all kinds of ridiculous things.

If you want to check out C3, I think the docs are just about all you need: <http://c3js.org/gettingstarted.html>

If you want to check out D3, Scott Murray's blog is where I recommend you start: <http://alignedleft.com/tutorials/d3>

<!channel>, <@U4M2ULFUK> is asking some great questions having to do with picking an API and I wanted to respond to them here so you all could see.

Whether or not you want to use an API that requires a key, or some kind of credentials is up to you. On the one hand setting up a key can be a pain, on the other hand, it's good to learn how to do it, and, might give you access to a really neat api, or, the ability to get more data from it than you otherwise might be able to. One thing is for sure, avoid using an API that you would have to pay for.

Also, I highly recommend (though it is not required) that you use an API that will give you JSON, and not one that will give you XML.

attachments.text:
Randomness tests (or tests for randomness), in data evaluation, are used to analyze the distribution of a set of data to see if it is random (patternless). In stochastic modeling, as in some computer simulations, the hoped-for randomness of potential input data can be verified, by a formal test for randomness, to show that the data are valid for use in simulation runs. In some cases, data reveals an obvious non-random pattern, as with so-called "runs in the data" (such as expecting random 0–9 but finding "4 3 2 1 0 4 3 2 1..." and rarely going above 4). If a selected set of data fails the tests, then parameters can be changed or other randomized data can be used which does pass the tests for randomness.
There are many practical measures of randomness for a binary sequence. These include measures based on statistical tests, transforms, and complexity or a mixture of these. A widely used collection of tests introduced by Marsaglia is called the Diehard Battery of Tests

SO Answer - DOM Levels are the versions of the specification for defining how the Document Object Model should work, similarly to how we have HTML4, HTML5, and CSS2.1 specifications.

The most recent spec is DOM Level 3, published in April 2004.

Additionally, there are pieces of the DOM spec that vendors can choose to implement, such as Core, HTML, and XML, as well as the event model. Depending on what is being built (a DOM parser, web browser layout engine, or javascript engine), the vendor may choose to implement some or all of the spec. Most modern web browsers implement all of the Level 3 spec.
